Award.AwardTitle: Young Physicist Support for UHECR2014 Symposium October 13-15, 2014 in Springdale, Utah.
Award.AbstractNarration:
The UHECR2014 Symposium is the third in a series of meetings dedicated to the physics and astrophysics of cosmic rays, with a particular emphasis on the ultrahigh energy regime. The meeting was held from October 13 to 15, 2014 in Springdale, Utah and brought together researchers from around the world. This award supports the participation of graduate students and postdocs in the UHECR2014 Symposium. The meeting was organized with plenary sessions and working groups focused on the spectrum, anisotropy, and composition of cosmic rays, cosmic ray theory, hadronic interaction models, new detector technologies, planned upgrades to existing experiments, and descriptions of future experiments.

Broader Impacts: The UHECR2014 Symposium helps to disseminate results in the field of cosmic ray physics. The study of cosmic rays is progressing rapidly, and it is important to bring together leaders in the field, plus young physicists such as graduate students and postdocs, to see the latest results and take part in discussions about the field. Proceedings of the symposium are planned for publication. Presentations and details of the symposium are publicly available on the symposium website. This award expands and enhances the experiences and education of young physicists.

Intellectual Merit:
The subject of cosmic ray physics and astrophysics is one of the most interesting in particle physics today. The main questions are: what is the composition and spectrum of cosmic rays, what are their sources, and how do they propagate from source to earth. In the ultrahigh energy regime there are two large experiments in operation: the Telescope Array and the Pierre Auger Observatory. Both have low- energy extensions; i.e., detector sets that observe cosmic ray air showers at lower energies. In addition there are a number of experiments dedicated to the lower energy region such as IceTop, Kascade Grande, and Tunka. Results from all of these experiments were presented and considerable discussion about similarities and differences ensued.
Working groups were formed for the symposium on topics of interest: Spectrum (E > 1 EeV), Spectrum (E < 1 EeV), Auger/IceCube/TA  Anisotropy, Auger/TA Anisotropy, Composition,  Hadronic Interactions, and Multimessenger Approach. Each was composed of representatives from the various experiments, and a report on each’s work was presented at the symposium. Several working groups are continuing their efforts, post-symposium, as well.
Broader Impacts:
The main broader impact of the UHECR2014 Symposium is in disseminating results in the field of cosmic ray physics. The study of cosmic rays is progressing rapidly, and it is important to bring together leaders in the field, plus young physicists such as graduate students and postdocs, to see the latest results and take part in discussions about the field. In the UHECR2014 Symposium about 75 physicists were brought together from around the world (North America, South America, Europe, and Asia) and a very lively set of talks and discussions resulted. The work of the symposium is in fact continuing since several of the working groups formed from the various experiments are continuing their work.
Summary talks will be published in a special issue of the journal, Progress in Theoretical and Experimental Physics. In addition, all speakers will be invited to provide submissions to be published in the JPS Conference Proceedings.  These are currently being finalized.  Finally, computer files fromspeakers’ talks have been uploaded to the symposium web site. http://uhecr2014.telescopearray.org/schedule.html
